newsitem.title: MONGOLIA: Russia's Primakov looking to boost Mongolian ties.
newsitem.headline: Russia's Primakov looking to boost Mongolian ties.

text.p: Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov, said on Wednesday that Moscow supported Mongolia's foreign policy and pledged to improve ties between the two Soviet-era allies.
Russia and Mongolia, both in the throes of painful economic transitions, shared many of the same foreign policy goals and views, Primakov told reporters in Mongolia's capital Ulan Bator.
Both countries had enjoyed stable ties for decades and now maintained relations on a basis of equality, Primakov said.

Landlocked Mongolia relied on aid from Moscow for nearly 70 years until a peaceful revolution in 1990 and the collapse of the Soviet Union a year later prompted the remote nation to emerge from isolation.
In Mongolia's parliamentary elections in June, a democratic coalition scored an upset victory over the ruling ex-communist party and embarked on ambitious market-oriented reforms.
"We also see that Mongolia's task in Asia is increasing," Primakov said, adding that Russia supported Mongolia's relations with China, the United States and European countries.
Primakov and Mongolia's Foreign Minister Altangerel signed an agreement aimed at boosting cooperation between the two foreign ministries, the two sides said in a joint statement.
Russia and Mongolia would hold talks on the possibility of setting up free trade zones in border areas and bolstering trade ties, the statement said.
Mongolian-Russian trade totals about $300 million a year and is likely to increase, Primakov said.
Mongolia's major export item to Russia is copper concentrate while its main import is petroleum.
Moscow and Ulan Bator also hoped to establish relations in areas such as information, human rights, education and science, the statement said.
Primakov said his trip would pave the way for a visit to Mongolia by Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, possibly in January. He also invited Altangerel to visit Russia.
